1123468992851656704.text: Sure, the Werther effect is a thing.  But there's only so much causality to go around in the world - like that Slate Star post I can't seem to find offhand, where Scott went through studies accounting for 1200% of all cancers or 300% of all mortality or whatever it was.

1123468991387844609.text: How did this study end up happening?  Did somebody notice a spike in a particular measured suicide rate, wonder what happened in April, and decide the Netflix show was at fault?  Did they try the 9-20 age range first, and not find a jump?  We can't know without preregistration.

1123468989823373314.text: To put it more sharply, imagine a Rationalist's Bet on this.  You would demand the bettor specify age range, time range, and required effect size *in advance*.  You would *not* accept, "I bet $500 that after this show airs, I can find some kind of increase in suicide rates."

1123468988481265664.text: If I had to pin down in one word what makes me leery here, it would be "preregistration".  They say Netflix was warned in advance.  Okay, so how about publishing in advance exactly what stats you'll use, like the "10-17" age range and month-by-month statistics?

1070095840608366594.text: An 'aligned' powerful AGI is one that can be pointed in any direction at all, even what seems like a simple task that isn't morally fascinating.  E.g. "Place, onto this particular plate here, two strawberries identical down to the cellular but not molecular level."

1070095399640215552.text: A 'powerful' AGI is one with a sufficiently huge potential impact that we have to align it.  Operationally, let's say an AGI is 'powerful' if it can invent and deploy biotechnology at least 10 years in advance of the human state of the art.
